text: Psalm 130
Hope for the Redemption of Yahweh
A song of ascents.\f + \fr Ps 130 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm \f*
Out of \add the\add* depths I call to you, O Yahweh.
“O Lord, hear my voice.
Let your ears be attentive
to the voice of my supplications.
If you, O Yah,\f + \fr 130:3 \ft A shortened form of “Yahweh” \f* should ⸤keep track of⸥\f + \fr 130:3 \ft Literally “keep” \f* iniquities,
O Lord, who could stand?
But with you \add is\add* forgiveness,
so that you may be feared.”
I await Yahweh; my soul awaits,
and I wait\f + \fr 130:5 \ft Or “hope,” here and v. \xt 7 \ft , though the Hebrew uses a different verbal stem in v. \xt 7 \ft \f* for his word.
My soul \add waits\add* for the Lord
more than watchmen for the morning.
Yes, \add more than\add* watchmen for the morning.
O Israel, wait\f + \fr 130:7 \ft Or “hope” \f* for Yahweh.
For with Yahweh \add there is\add* loyal love,
and with him \add there is\add* abundant redemption.
And he will redeem Israel
from all its iniquities.
